fields.description:
Bamboo should check for disk space, and if it detects that the server is running out of disk space the instance should be paused to avoid taking new builds.

It is possible to pause Bamboo server by calling a simple HTTP POST, so it would be just a matter of programming a script that will pause Bamboo when there would be less than 10% of disk free.
fields.summary: Bamboo instance should be paused automatically before server runs out of disk space

fields.description:
When the artifact copier brings a large (10-50mb) file from the build agent to the bamboo server, sometimes it is corrupt. This is most evident when the output of an MSBUILD parametrized deployment zip file is used with a bamboo deployment (MSDEPLOY).

If one opens this corrupt zip, and uses the test function of an archive program (winrar or 7zip for example) the output will show which parts corrupted.

I've tracked it to a end of stream error in java using bamboo logging and cannot get much farther.
fields.summary: Large files copied as artifacts get corrupted

fields.description: The webapp directory is empty.  It appears as if the contents were moved to atlassian-bamboo.  What about the plugins like artifactory that still may be looking for the webapp dir?
fields.summary: webapp dir is empty

fields.description:
There is currently no way to configure criteria or notifications for hung Deployments like there is for hung Build Plans.  

This is an issue because we often see that Deployments randomly hang on SCP tasks, and since there is no way to automate a notification, it ends up backing up a large number of other deployments until someone notices and manually stops the hung deployments.

Ideally there would be an option to automatically kill the hung deployment, based on some configurable criteria, but at the very minimum receiving a notifications would be helpful.
fields.summary: Add Hanging Notifications for Deployment Projects

fields.description: The [remote agent installation/configuration documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+remote+agent+capabilities+using+bamboo-capabilities.properties] does not reflect the current process in 5.4.2, particularly in relation to capabilities (shared capabilities are important). Please update this documentation so users have it as a point of reference.
fields.summary: Update Remote Agent / Capability Configuration Documentation

fields.description:
If Bamboo is configured for HTTPS connections, then the following happens. It does not occur when Bamboo is configured as HTTP://

*Description*
Bamboo has an open redirect on the login page which allows redirection to external sites. The {{os_destination}} parameter on the {{userlogin}} page (and other pages once logged in - see technical details below) allows you to redirect to any site if the URL is prefixed with two slashes.

*Attack Scenario*
This feature can help an attacker running a phishing scheme since many users only look at the domain name of a link before clicking on it and they will think they are going to a regular Bamboo page when in fact they are being redirected to a malicious site.
More info can be found in [CWE-601|http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/601.html] and the [WASC page|http://projects.webappsec.org/w/page/13246981/URL%20Redirector%20Abuse] on open redirects.

*Reproduction*
* Browse to the following link (replacing {{bamboo.example.com}} with your own test server).
* https://bamboo.example.com/userlogin!default.action?os_destination=%2F%2Fatlassian.com
* Log in, and see that your browser is redirected to atlassian.com.

Obviously, an attacker would have this redirect a victim to the attacker's own malicious site, not to atlassian.com. Also note that if you are already logged into Bamboo, browsing to the above link will redirect you _immediately_ to the malicious site.

*Technical Details*
A HTTP 302 redirect is performed on the {{os_destination}} parameter. An example response looks like this:
{code}HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
X-Seraph-LoginReason: OK
Location: https://atlassian.com
Content-Length: 0
Date: Tue, 22 Apr 2014 23:36:51 GMT{code}
I was only able to get redirects to work if the redirect URL begins with {{//}} (or {{%2F%2F}} when URL-encoded). Having special characters (such as the colon in {{http://}}) will redirect the user to the dashboard page, so it seems you can't redirect to the user to links with any other protocols.

If the user is already logged in, it doesn't seem to matter which page the {{os_destination}} parameter is on. Even if it's a page that doesn't exist, it will still redirect the user immediately. For example:
https://bamboo.example.com/ThisCanBeAnything?os_destination=%2F%2Fatlassian.com
https://bamboo.example.com/AnythingYouWant?os_destination=%2F%2Fatlassian.com

I tested this on version 5.2.2 of Bamboo, but it's possible other versions are vulnerable as well.

*Solution*
Confluence solves this problem by concatenating the site's URL with the contents of {{os_destination}}. So for our above example, it would redirect you to https://bamboo.example.com//atlassian.com which is still an example.com site.

Alternatively, you could have any {{os_destination}} that begins with {{//}} just redirect the user to the dashboard like what is done with special characters.

Finally, if having a redirect to another domain via a URL parameter is a useful feature, you could have a page warning people they are about to leave Bamboo.
fields.summary: Open redirect on Bamboo login page, only when configured for HTTPS connections

fields.description: According to comment, it would be beneficial on having {{[  ] Enable branch}} checked as default instead of having to enable it.
fields.summary: Property Enable branch enabled by default

fields.description:
Some installations will have the ant binary in other locations, even integrated in to the /bin structure of the OS. 

It would be beneficial if we were able to either use PATH to locate it, or enable a FQP to the binary to use.  When pointing to non-ANT_HOME locations, don't assume an extra "/bin/ant" is required.
fields.summary: Bamboo assumes ant binary will always be under ANT_HOME

fields.description: The HTML email breadcrumb is not rendering correctly in Firefox 28.0 on Windows 7, SP 1 (64 bit).
fields.summary: HTML email breadcrumb rendering error

fields.description:
* A branch is removed from baboo via the "Remove After" option in branch configuration
* Later a new commit is done to this removed plan, but bamboo will not "redetect" it

Is this intended behaviour? I think the branch should automatically be redeteced.
fields.summary: Bamboo is not redetecting removed branch after new commit

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to keep the last good build for a given build plan. This would help with the Build Expiry area to just keep a certain number of last good builds. We currently have the default set to keep last 15 builds w/ an expiry period of 2 days but lets say a team runs builds every hr and the last good build was 20 builds ago. That build would never be kept after the cleanup is done on the 2nd day. So, it would be nice to be to trap these good builds.
fields.summary: Ability to Keep Last Good Build

fields.description:
Would like ability to link a test Quarantine to a Jira ticket?

I've had to quarantine a test when a bug in the code breaks one; it would be really nice if I could somehow annotate the quarantined test with the matching Jira ticket # of the bug.
fields.summary: Manually linka  JIRA issue to a quarantined test

fields.description:
According to our Bamboo [Additional remote agent options|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Additional+remote+agent+options] documentation, the variable to set the remote agent home directory is: *-Dbamboo.home*. While our documentation is correct this variable is displayed incorrectly in Bamboo (Administration > Agents). Please check the attached screenshots. 

*Suggested resolution*
Please replace the variable *-dbamboo.Home* with *-Dbamboo.home* to match our documentation.
fields.summary: Misleading remote agent home directory variable

fields.description:
After successful integration of JIRA, Bamboo and Clover I am unable to see  the favorite plans in gadget. The second option with displaying selected plans works fine. 
After some debugging it looks like gadget is calling ProjectResource.getAllProjects method using REST, however despite defined favorite builds (with Clover integration enabled) nothing is returned.
fields.summary: Bamboo Clover Gadget is not displaying favorite plans in JIRA
Add support for R3 EC2 instances

fields.description: Sometimes you have some more arguments to pass to an build tool like MSBuild - for that it would be great to make the text boxes resizable.
fields.summary: Make Text boxes resizable in Task Configuration
Perforce commits listed in build result details that aren't part of current workspace

fields.description:
I like the Shared Credentials functionality.

However, it requires you to create source repositories as type "Git" instead of "Bitbucket", to be able to select the shared credentials.

It would be much easier if I could choose between user/pass and shared credentials when adding a Bitbucket source repo to a plan. I'm wondering though if it is possible to load the list of repositories without having a bitbucket user/pass...
fields.summary: Use shared credentials with Bitbucket repository

fields.description:
The docs at https://developer.atlassian.com/display/DOCS/Web+Item+Plugin+Module
indicate that variables should be references as $variable, and this is supported in JIRA and Confluence. 

Bamboo requires ${variable}.

Either the docs should be updated, or Bamboo should be brought inline with velocity syntax and the documentation.
fields.summary: Bamboo does not support official atlassian-plugin.xml syntax

fields.description:
When looking at the requirements for a job, there's a link that says "N agents" (referring to how many agents can build the job). When hovered, the link triggers an inline dialog to appear, but unfortunately when you try to move your mouse into the dialog it dismisses very aggressively.

The result is that it's hard to investigate the agents. See the attached video.
fields.summary: "63 agents are capable…" inline dialog dismisses too aggressively

fields.description:
When configuring the Artifact Download task in a Bamboo job, it is necessary to select the Source Plan from a drop-down menu.

This menu is limited to 10 entries, in alphabetical order (by plan name). If the plan you want isn't in the first 10, you can't select it.

This affects the current OD version - 5.5-OD-02-0005
fields.summary: Source Plan for artifact download task is limited to 10 entries
Stock windows images do not properly handle .Net file access

fields.description:
Hello, 

I want to use EBS with Bamboo ondemand as described on this guide: 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO030/Configuring+Elastic+Instances+to+use+the+EBS

I'm trying to obtain the scripts: 

 - createInitialVolume.sh
 - rewarmEbsSnapshot.sh

This post from Michael Knight:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=253231643

indicates the scripts I need are in the Elastic Image Assembly however the links to all versions of this package 404. 

Eg - 

http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/downloads/bamboo-elastic-agent-5.0-beta2.zip

http://downloads.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/downloads/bamboo-elastic-agent-3.4.5.zip

Please advice me on where I should obtain these scripts. 

Thanks, 

Ben
fields.summary: EBS Scripts / Elastic Agent Assembly Not Available
Ability to run customized builds with saved configuration

fields.description:
As a prerequiste for installation of Bamboo in our company, we need support for MS SQL 2012 (64bit).
Do you plan to update your included drivers to support this SQL server release?
fields.summary: MS SQL 2012

fields.description:
Bamboo should provide the ability to change the "My Bamboo" string in the dashboard to 
read "Dashboard" for internal workflow reasons. 

After discussing with development, this does not seem to be exposed as a element that can be currently customised.
fields.summary: Ability to customise "My Bamboo" menu banner item

fields.description:
Some mail and list servers have problems processing header fields. It is also desirable to be able to customise these as needed.

For example Sympa is unable to correctly pass "Auto-Submitted:" correctly. While this is strictly speaking a bug with the mail/list server, it would be good to be able to expose the email header for customisation. 

(It also appears that this particular header item is not added to mail set by other Atlassian products.)
fields.summary: Ability to customise email header fields

fields.description:
Certain NASes (Synology) come with an incomplete SSH implementation. They have SFTP, but no SCP. 

To work around this, I extended the bamboo-scp-plugin's logic to present an SFTP option. The implementation is admittedly naive at the moment (not a Java guy, sorry), but it was fairly simple to follow the SCP class's example.

Since there was an existing plugin for older Bamboos, I figured there might be some interest in making this a part of the actual plugin. I've included my changes, just in case they're of use to someone.
fields.summary: Add SFTP Support

fields.description: It just says its not supported.  Does not tell you how to fix it.
fields.summary: Unhelpful error message if merging disabled due to missing git executable

fields.description:
The main issue here is the case sensitivity in the email. 

If we have a Git author's email <john.doe@mycompany.com> and a Bamboo user <John.Doe@mycompany.com>, the auto-link won't work. Case sensitivity should not matter for email addresses.

Because of this, after builds are run and Bamboo detects a commit change, it won't email users until the auto-link is manually done.
fields.summary: Case sensitivity prevents auto-linking of Authors

fields.description:
h4. Problem:
Unable to retrieve Bitbucket repository URL using Bamboo variables
Documentation: [Bamboo variables|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+variables#Bamboovariables-Build-specificvariables]

h4. Duplication Steps:
# Create build plan
# Add Bitbucket repository to build plan
# Add ${bamboo_repository_git_repositoryUrl} to startup script
# Run build
(i) URL not returned

h4. Workaround:
Use Bitbucket REST API:
{code}
curl -u [username] -p -H GET https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/[username]/[repo_slug]
{code}
fields.summary: need repositoryUrl build variable for BitBucket

Upon starting up Bamboo with Tomcat latest version, the following error will be returned.

	at com.atlassian.soy.impl.TemplateSetFactory$TemplateSetBuilder.access$200(TemplateSetFactory.java:81)

{noformat}

This is not aligned with the [Supported Platform|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms], that specified that it should be compatible with all Tomcat 7.

*Steps to replicate*
# Download Tomcat 7.0.53
# Point the webapp to Bamboo webapp
{code}
<Host name="localhost"  appBase="webapps"
            unpackWARs="true" autoDeploy="true">

                    <!--<Resource name="UserTransaction" auth="Container" type="javax.transaction.UserTransaction"-->
                              <!--factory="org.objectweb.jotm.UserTransactionFactory" jotm.timeout="60"/>-->
                    <Manager pathname=""/>
                </Context>

            </Host>
{code}
# Startup Bamboo and you will get the error

fields.description: We use variables in the environment to control server names and such for the various tasks. Cloning an environment would allow the addition of new environments with just variable updates.
fields.summary: Add the ability to clone environments in a deployment project

fields.description:
Currently, deployment project must be linked to a build plan. This is ideal for projects that require code compilation and packaging, however, not all cases require code compilation.

For example, ASP.NET websites are just files that are copied over to the server. Although we can create a build plan and artifact for the website files, it is not ideal because our websites are over 1GB, while all we need is code checkout which is automatically cached at Git level, then deploy delta changes.

Definitely, I can easily workaround this by creating a dummy build plan that does nothing, then link it to the deployment projects -- which is what I'm currently doing. But just thought standalone deployment project would be a great addition to Bamboo.
fields.summary: Standalone deployment project

fields.description:
In Bamboo, variables with "password" in its key are shown as * mask in the user interface. Smart.

But not the build log. Not smart :)

I'm expecting all password variables to be masked, whether in the user interface or in the written build log. That's the whole point of the "password", right?

Thanks!
fields.summary: Password variables must be masked in the build log

fields.description:
Plan Branch release-R-21-2 (details first screenshot) has a build (second screenshot), but that build doesn't show up in the build results for the plan (third screenshot) when I go to deploy. Also, the plan branch does have multiple releases, but they are from another plan! (fourth screenshot).

Also note that in Screenshot #2, the Branch Summary indicates that it is "Included in build project" R-18, which seems wrong.

I know that we (Rosetta Stone) are locally hosted, but any help you can give would be appreciated.

Thanks!

For other people searching for this: "There are no successful build results on selected plan branch"
fields.summary: Plan Branch with successful build doesn't show up when creating a release

fields.description: When we add a shared repository, to a plan, we don`t have the option to override certain settings like the use of submodules or excluding the changesets. Basically we should allow all the advanced options up-datable on per plan basis
fields.summary: Allow overriding of the shared repository settings at plan level

fields.description:
Fixed test shown in test results multiple time in subsequent builds. Where in fact, the test was fixed in earlier build but it is still showing up as a fixed tests in the next builds.

!fixed_test.png!
fields.summary: Fixed test shown in test results multiple time in subsequent builds

fields.description:
We're currently seeing that the Bamboo server becomes instable as soon as the build queue reaches exceedes 300 or 400. Unfortunately, there is no way to tell Bamboo to stop queue new jobs beside the pause button (which requires manual intervention).

I suggest to have a configurable maximium of builds that can be queue. If the number is reached, Bamboo should not queue any new builds but wait until a safe limit is reached (e.g. 10% or 20% below the limit). This limit doesn't necessarily need to be configurable through the ui and can be hard coded or e.g. a system property.
fields.summary: Allow to set an upper limit for the build queue

fields.description:
Nowadays the permission granted for a user to edit a deployment project in order to create a release also grants that user permission to edit the deployment project tasks.

This is not ideal for some customers, so it would be great if this could be separated in two different permissions.

It would also be good if the permission for create project and deploy project weren't bundled under 'admin' permissions.
fields.summary: Deployments - Separate permission to create releases from permission to edit project tasks

While adding a user repository for JIRA within Bamboo, I immediately got my administration privileges revoked and the local account I made was deleted. The name of the account was not used on any other systems.

http://gyazo.com/95c40ec98dabe271a8a6b31c5c933560

fields.description:
Hi,

We have a trigger override on our branch builds which starts a build on a repository change - but we would also like to have a daily build in addition (to trigger the automated merge with changes from master each day).

thanks
fields.summary: Allow multiple custom triggers for branch build

fields.description:
When a failed build is re-run, the logs are concatenated on every build. So when we re-run x number of times, the tasks are run x-number of times as well. It will be nice if we can separate each re-run with a marker something like:

{{ build	07-Apr-2014 11:17:07	==== Re-running failed job. Log messages appended. ==== }}
fields.summary: Add markers in the build logs of re-run builds

fields.description:
This issue is as described 

"I was able to reproduce the behavior when regular plans started EC2 instances and worked fine, but the deployment project stayed queued after passing the configured 1 minute threshold. See the attached screenshots.
The deployment ran successfully after manually starting an elastic agent."

This issue is currently in JIRA under BAM-13588, however it is erroneously marked as resolved. I'm sorry to purposely duplicate a ticket, but it seems the original ticket, despite being critical and open since last August, seems to be being ignored.

*Please do not close this as a duplicate without re-opening BAM-13588*
fields.summary: Deployment projects don't start EC2 instances automatically

fields.description:
*Problem Description*
When configuring custom SSO or authenticator, the login or logout would be redirected to certain page. However in Bamboo the logout could not be redirected. It works well with JIRA.

*Steps to replicate*
# Navigate to {{$BAMBOO-INSTALL/atlassian-bamboo/WEB-INF/classes/seraph-config.xml}}
# Edit the {{param-value}} parameter to any page in Bamboo
{noformat}
            <param-name>logout.url</param-name>
            <param-value>/userLogout.action</param-value>
{noformat}
# Restart Bamboo
# Try to replicate the issue by logging in and notice that it won't be redirected
# If it is configured in JIRA it will work fine
fields.summary: Logout parameter didin't work in Bamboo seraph-config.xml

fields.description: Right now, you get the quarantines of the "main" branch when you create a branch.  We often have main development branches for multiple software versions.  If you branch off of version 1, you want the quarantines of version 1, if you branch off of version 2, you want the quarantines from version 2.
fields.summary: Add the ability to pick branch to inherit quarantined tests from

fields.description:
Currently the Nunit Runner task is only capable of running in build projects but it would make sense to allow it to run in Deployment projects as well. Here is a use case:

I would like to do these actions in this order:

1. Build my solution
2. Run unit tests
3. Deploy to staging
4. Run Integration/Acceptance tests on deployed software through NUnit
5. Deploy to production
6. Run Integration/Acceptance tests on deployed software through NUnit

If the NUnit runner task would be available in Deployment Projects then this scenario would be trivial.
fields.summary: Implement NUnit runner in Deployment Projects

fields.description:
One of our unit tests prints out a NULL character (0x00) when failing.

The NULL character ends up in the message tag of the XML result file.

Bamboo seems to be silently ignoring the NUnit XML parse failure and the failing unit test result in this XML file is ignored (but not the successful ones that ran before). Any trace of this test just vanishes from the Bamboo build and the build is greenly marked as having passed.

In other words: one failing unit test, yet Bamboo says everything is fine.
fields.summary: NUnit Parser stage does not report errors when parsing an invalid XML input

fields.description:
As for now the artifact of Bamboo can be deployed to any environment without any condition of it is deployed in previous state of environment.

For example there are three environment:
DEV -> QA -> PROD

It would be good if Bamboo has restriction, that the deployment should be deployed in DEV environment, before it can be deployed to QA, and so on.
fields.summary: Restriction in deploying to some environment when it wasn't deployed to previous environment (Gated process)

fields.description:
I'm not completely sure how to reproduce this yet, but I noticed that we were losing our quarantine history. I initially thought it was an OPS issue (within our company), but looking at our failures I notice that they all seem to follow the same pattern. 

Our build process is as follows: 
1. Compile
2. Run unit tests
3. Deploy to a remote server (using ansible)
4. Run integration tests
5. Save the build artifact.

We have a handful of quarantined tests (which we'll get round to tidying up one day ;)), they are all integration tests. As long as we achieve a successful deploy, then even if some integration tests fail, the quarantine history works as expected. However if the deployment step fails, then none of the integration tests are run (rightly so), our issue is that in this case the quarantine history disappears for our integration tests, and only starts to build up again once the deployment is successful (and integration tests start running again). The behaviour I would expect is for the history to continue, but show a 'did not run' icon, or some equivalent. This still isn't ideal because several successive deployment failures would pollute the history slightly with irrelevant information (at the end of the day I want to know what the success-failure ratio is), but then I'm not sure how much history is preserved... If the full history was preserved, then being shown 'did not run' wouldn't affect this ratio.

If I had to make a black-box guess I would say that there's an assumption that because the test didn't run it has been removed from the build, and its quarantine history can be removed, but of course that's just conjecture. :)
fields.summary: Quarantine history should not be lost when tests don't run due to an early failure

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to display plan branches just like project plans (see attachment for example).
So we can see all plans and all plan branches statuses in one screen.
fields.summary: Plan branches visibility

fields.description:
We would like Bamboo to offer a global build numbering scheme, where the build number is enough to uniquely identify the build - regardless of whether that build happened on a branch or on the 'default' branch.

If this is implemented, this number should subsequently be exposed as a Bamboo variable that can be used in deployment projects and in release naming schemes.
fields.summary: Implement a global build numbering scheme that doesn't start at '1' on branch builds

fields.description:
Currently each Bamboo Plan and Branch is individually polling repositories for changes. This can cause some performance degradation especially for larger instances that poll the repo hundreds (or more) times through the process of normal building/deploying.

It could improve performance if the polling done by the notification processes could be changed to a per repository poll instead of a per branch/plan poll.
fields.summary: Reduce repository polling for Bamboo notifications

fields.description: In cases where the server goes offline an admin wants the Bamboo server to fail over to a redundant server.

fields.description:
When a Perforce workspace is deleted or unavailable, and a plan run, the error/exception returned will be 
{code}
Perforce can't be retrieved due to no output from:
p4 changes -m 1 -s submitted //<workspace>/...". 
{code}

To clarify this, can we check once for the existence of the workspace prior to the start of the stage or job. This would improve error 
reporting for customers, i.e. "Workspace X not found."
fields.summary: Improve error reporting when Perforce client/workspace not found

fields.description: Currently the build scripts that Bamboo runs determine the version number which is external to Bamboo. It would be great to have a version to be created and deployed when a build successfully runs under a certain plan. There should be someway to communicate the version to the Bamboo deployment project. Currently, it appears that this is only works through plan variables or build variables.
fields.summary: Allow setting deployment release versions from a variable created during the build to support automatic deployments

fields.description:
I'm embedding three dashboards in an html page using frames. One on the left and two stacked on the right (This is for a dumb screen which can only be pointed at a single page and can't run bamboo) 
As I understand it, when the numbers of the jobs exceeded certain limits, then an extra columnis added and the jobs wrap.
This works fine for the tall dashboard on the left, but the two on the right only start wrapping when the page size is exceeded, not the frame height. This results in the lower jobs not wrapping and disappearing. 

Could Dashboards be changed so it detects this situation?

{code:xml}
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>

<head>
    <title>Bamboo Dashboard</title>
</head>

<frameset cols="50%, 50%">
    <frame src="http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8085/telemetry.action" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" noresize="noresize">
    <frameset rows="50%, 50%">
        <frame src="http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8085/telemetry.action?filter=showPlanAndBranches&planKey=IOSLD-IOSKHFEATURE" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" noresize="noresize">
        <frame src="http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8085/telemetry.action?filter=showPlanAndBranches&planKey=WEBAPI-WEBAPIFEATURE" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="0" noresize="noresize">
                
    </frameset>
</frameset>
</html>
{code}
fields.summary: Dashboards embedded in custom html frameset pages height is based on page height

fields.description:
From https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-13228
Given this directory structure in artifact:
{noformat}
+ dir_a
| + dir_a_1
|   + file a_1_1
+ dir_b
| + dir_b_1
|   + file b_1_1
+ dir_c
| + dir_c_1
|   + file c_1_1
{noformat}
remote location will contain structure like this
{noformat}
+ dir_a_1
| + file a_1_1
+ dir_b
| + dir_b_1
|   + file b_1_1
+ dir_c
| + dir_c_1
|   + file c_1_1
{noformat}

This is reproducible on atlassian-bamboo-scp-plugin:5.0.5 (used in Bamboo 5.1.0) and on most recent atlassian-bamboo-scp-plugin:5.0.8
fields.summary: Bamboo SCP plugin copies directories wrong

fields.description:
I am developing a bamboo plugin and am following the Run Wired Tests with the Plugin Test Console tutorial. My wired test runs without a problem from the Plugin Test Console, the first time. However when I edit the test and click the run button, the fast dev page is not displayed. Instead I am redirected to a 404 page:

http://localhost:6990/bamboo/plugins/servlet/undefined/plugins/servlet/fastdev?origUrl=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%3A6990%2Fbamboo%2Fplugins%2Fservlet%2Fit-test-console%3Fbundle%3Dcom.carolynvs.trade_depot-tests

When I remove the plugins/servlet/undefined path from the URL, I am able to resolve to the fastdev page.

Additionally the link to the plugin test console is incorrect. When I open the dev toolbox the link is this: http://localhost:6990/bamboohttp://localhost:6990/bamboo/plugins/servlet/it-test-console when it should be http://localhost:6990/bamboo/plugins/servlet/it-test-console.

Bamboo 5.4.2 (4208) / Atlassian SDK 4.2.18 / FastDev 2.3 / Dev Toolbox 2.0.12
fields.summary: Fast dev plugin not behaving as expected

My problem is that I have a deployment plan that deploys a release linked with a build plan wich contains jira issues.

Once I run the deployment plan and it is succeeded that is no problem, the e-mail notification comes with the link to the Jira issues.

But if the deployment plan is not succeeded and i have to rerun this deployment plan the notification email comes without the jira issues.

fields.description:
Configuration :
* a shared Git repo, initially configured with shallow fetching option activated
* the repo is accessed through ssh, submodules support is enabled
* multiple plan using this repo, each having multiple branches


Steps to reproduce :
* disable shallow fetching option on the shared repo
* run a branch on a plan that uses the modified repo

Result :
The run logs still show "Will try to do a shallow fetch".
The only way we could find to force a full fetch was to declare a plan-specific repo with the option disabled.

(+) Update : the shallow fetch seems to also happen with the non-shared repository with the option disabled. So I cannot find a way to disable that shallow fetch functionality.
fields.summary: Cannot disable shallow fetch on shared Git repo

fields.description:
We have a case where duplicate acl_object_identity with object_id_identity=99999 exist. Cause of that is unknown for now.
In result adding global permissions for new user or group is impossible.

Let's analyze acl code to better protect it against creating duplicates.
fields.summary: Analyze acl code in Bamboo for potential race conditions in global permissions

fields.description:
h3. Problem Description

The release autocomplete dropdown (_Promote existing release to this environment_) is slow to populate on {{deploy/selectVersionForExecute.action}}. The XHR to {{/rest/api/latest/search/versions?searchTerm=&start-index=0&chronologicalOrder=true&max-results=10&deploymentProjectId=24707073}} appears to be the main offender – taking up to 1 minute to return on some datasets.

h3. Suggested Solution
 * Improve the performance of the retrieval and population of the results in the control.
 * For a lot of users, the most recent result is the one required to deploy. If we could send it through in the page load so Start Deployment can be clicked straight away, that could also alleviate the problem and provide a more usable experience.
fields.summary: Improve performance and usability of Release autocomplete dropdown on selectVersionForExecute.action

Website
These are 2 of many plans that have been cloned from a template I have created containing a code, tasks and a variable: package. In each plan I set the value for package to either 'network' or 'website', etc...
When running these plans individually they work as required and create a final *.tar.gz file in ${bamboo.package}/build/output/ (eg network/build/output)

I am now creating a 'Master' plan to combine Network and Website into one aggregated *.tar.gz
In Master I set the variable package to 'master', add 2 Artifact Download tasks, point them at the required Network and Website plan's artifact and run.

The logs below show the Master plan's Network Artifact Download task, and that it is substituting my {bamboo.package} variable to 'master' instead of 'network', meaning it can not find the file.

Why is it using the master variable when it is in the network plan, this is the same in the website plan's artifact download too preventing me to locate the artifacts.

Log file below

fields.description:
Our scenario:

We primarily build Java web applications (usually packaged as ears) using Maven.  Currently, each project has the following Bamboo builds:

Build - Monitors "master" and continuously builds snapshots (e.g. 1.2.12-SNAPSHOT).  Snapshots are deployed to our Nexus maven repo upon build completion (in our snapshot repos)

Release - Manually triggered when the project is ready to begin the QA process and potentially be deployed to PROD (e.g. 1.2.12).  Releases are deployed to our Nexus maven repo upon build completion (in our release repos)

Site - Maven site build (documentation, static code analysis, etc...)

Deploy Dev - Builds a new snapshot and deploys to our DEV environment (this is NOT a "Deployment Project", we have had these for years)

We would like to use the new-ish "Deployment Project" feature of Bamboo, but it doesn't seem to fit our current workflow since it only allows a single build plan source.

We have 4 environments (DEV -> UAT -> QA -> PROD).  The way we currently work is:

1 - Deploy snapshots (from the main "build" plan) very often to DEV.  We also deploy these snapshots to UAT for clients to test and provide feedback.  UAT is the furthest a SNAPSHOT can go in the deployment chain.

2 - When features and bugs are complete for a version, then we trigger the "Release" plan.  This uses the maven release plugin to take the project out of snapshot, deploy the release to Nexus, increment the POM versions and put the project back in SNAPSHOT mode for continued development.

We then take the RELEASE and deploy it to DEV, then UAT, then QA and (hopefully) PROD.

Our Problem:

The problem we have is that "Deployment Projects" can only source from one build plan.  If we pick the "build" plan as our source, then we would end up promoting SNAPSHOTs up through the environments (which isn't permitted past UAT).

If we pick the "release" build as our source, then we won't be able to deploy SNAPSHOTs to DEV and UAT.

Ideal Solution - Allow multiple sources:

In a perfect world, we would have the ability to source artifacts from two build plans.  That way, when it comes to deploying the latest snapshot to DEV for testing, we could source from "build".  When it time to promote an actual release through the environments, we would source from "release".

I realize we could "edit" the build plan every time we want to switch from "build" to "release" as the source, but that seems clunky and error prone.

Is there any chance that multiple build sources could be included as a feature in a future release of Bamboo?
fields.summary: Deployment Project sourced from multiple builds
